intro: Acacia vittata, commonly known as the white wattle, is a flowering plant native to eastern Australia. It is a small to medium-sized shrub that typically grows in coastal and sandy soils. The plant features slender, often twisted stems and produces small, yellow flowers in clusters during the spring and summer. Its leaves are bipinnate, consisting of numerous tiny, hairless leaflets. Acacia vittata is valued for its ornamental appeal and is often cultivated in gardens for its attractive foliage and floral display.

Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees known for their distinctive compound leaves and often thorny structures. Its species is Acacia vittata, a specific type of acacia found in certain regions, characterized by its unique morphological features and ecological adaptations.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acacia vittata is primarily native to Western Australia. It is commonly found in the southern regions of the state, particularly in the areas of the Geraldton and Shark Bay regions. This plant thrives in sandy soils and is often associated with coastal and inland habitats. It is well adapted to the arid and semi-arid climates of the region. Acacia vittata is an important component of the local flora and plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils.

It is commonly found in disturbed soils and along roadsides in regions where it has been planted. The plant thrives in dry, sandy environments and is often used for its hardy nature and ability to fix nitrogen. However, it can become invasive in some areas, outcompeting native vegetation.
